hypothesis: Systematic risk (shared false belief in CORE.md) propagates to 100% of spawned agents; idiosyncratic risk (per-agent estimation errors) is uncorrelated and averages out via majority vote

part_a_systematic.method: Planted 3 false beliefs in experiments/finance/test-beliefs-fin2.json; spawned N=3 parallel agents; asked each to report the beliefs from the file; also asked their own independent knowledge
planted_errors: Great Wall is ~500 miles (800 km) long [true: ~21,196 km]
Amazon flows into Pacific Ocean [true: Atlantic]
part_a_systematic.verdict: CONFIRMED: systematic risk (shared false context) propagates universally to all agents

part_b_idiosyncratic.method: N=3 parallel agents on identical Fermi estimation (piano tuners in Chicago) and historical estimation (Constantinople peak population). No planted errors.

q1_stats.note: B2 cites canonical answer as ~125, B3 gets closest

part_b_idiosyncratic.verdict: CONFIRMED: idiosyncratic errors are uncorrelated across agents; majority vote recovers reasonable answer for Q2; Q1 shows genuine per-agent divergence

key_finding: Finance isomorphism F-FIN2 CONFIRMED. Systematic risk (shared wrong belief) = 100% propagation; cannot be diversified away. Idiosyncratic risk (per-agent estimation noise) = low correlation; majority vote is effective remedy.
swarm_design_implications: CORE.md belief hygiene is more important than agent count for accuracy
A single wrong belief in shared state infects 100% of agents — belief-level errors are non-diversifiable
Per-agent hallucinations/estimation errors are diversifiable via majority vote (F-FIN1 complement)
The two risk types require different remedies: systematic → fix source; idiosyncratic → increase N and take majority vote
This implies swarm should have strong belief-challenge protocol (F-FIN2 risk) AND ensemble mechanisms for estimation tasks (F-FIN1 benefit)
